node.title: Modelling predicting 25,000 COVID cases a day by January in NSW was 'very preliminary'
node.alt: People in cars at a drive through testing clinic
node.description: The author of the COVID modelling report used by the NSW Health Minister to urge the community to stay vigilant ahead of a surge in casesÂ backs his findings but says they were very preliminary.
node.content:
["The modelling predicting a 25,000 rise in COVID-19 cases is \"very preliminary\" and has not factored in a potential increase in booster shots, says the report's author.", "However, associate professor James Wood\u00a0backed his projections, which found \"four-fold growth in cases per week was very consistent with what we are seeing here as well as international contexts.\"", "On Wednesday, NSW Health Minister Brad Hazzard cited research from Dr Wood's Public Health Unit at the University of New South Wales which suggested a possible surge of up to 25,000 COVID cases a day by the end of January.", "\"That takes it, on my maths, to about 175,000 in a week,\" Mr Hazzard said.", "\"That is one big difference from the 1,360 today, which is already a cause for concern.\"", "", "
Mr Hazzard says based on his calculations using the modelling, NSW could see\u00a0175,000 COVID cases a week.(AAP: Bianca De Marchi)
", "Mr Hazzard noted the modelling would need refining but used the data to urge the public to keep taking safety precautions over the holiday season.", "\"The inputs to those sort of mathematical equations \u2026 are always difficult,\" he said.", "\"A lot of work that went into that algorithm has been done from the UK and South Africa, which aren't exactly analogous, we know that.\"", "His comments came on the same day NSW Premier Dominic Perrottet followed through on plans to scrap almost all remaining restrictions, despite COVID cases surging from 804 on Tuesday to 1,360 by Wednesday.", "Dr Wood said his modelling factored in the likely number of Omicron cases across the state in the last week, along with international and national evidence about the transmission of the virus, and the current booster uptake.", "", "
Dr Wood backs the projections outlined in his report.(Supplied: UNSW)
", "\"The scenario described by the Minister [Brad Hazzard] is one we feel is likely \u2026 However, the projections were very preliminary,\" he said.", "He also pointed out that if any significant changes were made \u2014 such as restrictions being re-introduced, booster doses increasing quickly or people changing their behaviour as perceived risk increases, \"each of these would be expected to slow growth \u2014 however, we have not conducted detailed modelling of these scenarios.\"", "Mr Hazzard noted that prior drastic warnings\u00a0of tens of thousands of deaths due to COVID infections were averted because the public paid attention.", "\"Because the community came out and responded, because they wore masks, because we all kept the 1.5-metre\u00a0social distance, because we did all we were asked to do by NSW Health, we managed to keep the deaths down considerably.", "\"So we may not get 25,000 new cases every day, but we could.\"", "", "
Why we hear about some COVID-19 variants more than others
"]
